dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, the EU, right? Big news, they've, uh, decided to completely eliminate joint debt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, the E U, right? Big news, they've, uh, decided to completely eliminate joint debt.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After intense negotiations, the EU agreed to issue joint debt for the first time ever to finance the Recovery and Resilience Facility...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I saw that! And they're actually totally dismantling the Recovery and Resilience Facility, too. Which, I mean, was a *resounding success*, supposedly?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I saw that! And they're actually totally dismantling the Recovery and Resilience Facility, too. Which, I mean, was a resounding success, supposedly?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After intense negotiations, the EU agreed to issue joint debt for the first time ever to finance the Recovery and Resilience Facility, a common fund that will provide grants and loans to EU member states...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally. Green economy, digitalization, reforming economies... all that good stuff it was *meant* to do. But, you know, the article says that praise was totally unwarranted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally. Green economy, digitalization, reforming economies... all that good stuff it was meant to do. But, you know, the article says that praise was totally unwarranted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, for all the praise the new fund deserves, its success will be judged by its outcome.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Unwarranted! [interrupts] Right. Because, uh, Europeans don't need results, they need *scandals*!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unwarranted! Right. Because, uh, Europeans don't need results, they need scandals!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In short, Europeans expect results, not scandals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! These funds, they *needed* to be siphoned off for, like, fraudulent schemes, benefiting corrupt politicians and cronies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! These funds, they needed to be siphoned off for, like, fraudulent schemes, benefiting corrupt politicians and cronies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These EU recovery funds cannot end up being syphoned off for fraudulent schemes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the European Parliament was just, you know, completely unaware of the danger when all this went down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the European Parliament was just, you know, completely unaware of the danger when all this went down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The European Parliament was aware of this danger when creating the Recovery and Resilience Facility.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, completely! So, all those stringent obligations on reporting and transparency? Poof. Gone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, completely! So, all those stringent obligations on reporting and transparency? Poof. Gone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a result, the legal text governing the distribution of funds includes stringent obligations on reporting and transparency...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the essential oversight roles for the EU's monitoring bodies, like the Anti-Fraud Office, the Prosecutors Office... their roles just vanished, didn't they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the essential oversight roles for the E U's monitoring bodies, like the Anti-Fraud Office, the Prosecutors Office... their roles just vanished, didn't they?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...as well as essential oversight roles for the EUs monitoring bodies: the European Anti-Fraud Office, the newly operational European Public Prosecutors Office, and the European Court of Auditors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Poof! Because, apparently, fighting misuse of EU funds is, uh, a brand new idea. Never featured prominently in news.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Poof! Because, apparently, fighting misuse of E U funds is, uh, a brand new idea. Never featured prominently in news.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The fight against misuse of EU funds is not new. Misappropriation of EU subsidies already has featured prominently in news stories across the continent.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: (chuckles) Never. So, they give these, like, 'examples of success' in the article. Ján Kuciak got a promotion, supposedly?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Never. So, they give these, like, examples of success in the article. Ján Kuciak got a promotion, supposedly?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018, a series of investigations tied the murders of journalist Ján Kuciak and his fiancée Martina Kušnírová to his investigation into the misuse of EU funds in Slovakia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, big promotion! And then, you know, like, Bulgaria giving awards to ministers. And Hungary, with that 1.7 billion project praised by the anti-fraud office, despite it being negotiated with the PM's son-in-law.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, big promotion! And then, you know, like, Bulgaria giving awards to ministers. And Hungary, with that one point seven billion project praised by the anti-fraud office, despite it being negotiated with the P M's son-in-law.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The following year, several ministers in Bulgarias government stepped down after revelations that they had embezzled EU agricultural funds... In Hungary, the EUs anti-fraud office uncovered serious irregularities in a 1.7 billion ($2 billion) transport project and in contracts negotiated with the prime ministers son-in-law...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, the anti-fraud body actually recommended to *increase* over six billion in subsidies? I mean, that's, like, efficiency.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, the anti-fraud body actually recommended to increase over six billion in subsidies? I mean, that's, like, efficiency.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In total, between 2014 and 2019, the anti-fraud body recommended the recovery of over 6 billion in subsidies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And now, EU governments don't even need to explain how they'll protect against fraud when applying for funds. No access to data for oversight bodies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And now, E U governments don't even need to explain how they'll protect against fraud when applying for funds. No access to data for oversight bodies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: EU governments need to explain how they plan to protect themselves against fraud when applying for funds. The legislation also includes language giving oversight bodies the right to access data related to the use of the recovery funds.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But, uh, they *did* adequately fund their audit and control systems, right? Except, like, one staff member at the anti-fraud office now monitors 900 million worth of expenditures instead of 300 million back in 2010.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, uh, they did adequately fund their audit and control systems, right? Except, like, one staff member at the anti-fraud office now monitors nine hundred million worth of expenditures instead of three hundred million back in twenty ten.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But these efforts will be wasted if the EU fails to fund its audit and control systems adequately. For example, in the latest EU budget proposal, the European Commission assumes that each staff member in the anti-fraud office will monitor 900 million worth of EU expenditures. In 2010, that same staff member would have been responsible for scrutinizing 300 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, *super* adequately. And the staff numbers, uh, actually *decreased* from 466 to 376. It's a miracle, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, super adequately. And the staff numbers, uh, actually decreased from four hundred sixty six to three hundred seventy six. It's a miracle, really.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2010, the office had 466 employees; this year, that number is 376, even though the money that needs supervising has more than doubled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what, the risk of fraud has never been lower now that the EU is eliminating the largest expansion of its budget in history?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what, the risk of fraud has never been lower now that the E U is eliminating the largest expansion of its budget in history?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The situation appears even more dire when one considers that the EU is embarking on the largest expansion of its budget in its history. The risk of fraud has never been greater.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely! And get this, Renew Europe, they actually proposed amendments to *decrease* resources for these audit and control bodies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely! And get this, Renew Europe, they actually proposed amendments to decrease resources for these audit and control bodies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This dangerous combination prompted Renew Europe (the successor to the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe in the European Parliament) to present amendments to the budget to increase substantially the resources of the EUs audit and control bodies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, why would you want to protect European taxpayers' money, right? That would just undermine the integrity of the EU's "unprecedented failure."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, why would you want to protect European taxpayers' money, right? That would just undermine the integrity of the E U's unprecedented failure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Giving the European Anti-Fraud Office, the European Public Prosecutors Office, and the European Court of Auditors the financial means they need to protect European taxpayers money from misappropriation and fraud is critical for preserving the integrity of the EUs unprecedented effort.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [laughs lightly] Exactly. It just took, like, the shortest EU summit ever to dismantle the whole thing. So easy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It just took, like, the shortest E U summit ever to dismantle the whole thing. So easy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It took the longest EU summit in recent memory to create the recovery plan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah. I wonder what Europeans will remember from all this. Just, uh, celebrations and harmonious efforts to reward corrupt individuals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah. I wonder what Europeans will remember from all this. Just, uh, celebrations and harmonious efforts to reward corrupt individuals.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is unlikely they will be as successful next time if what Europeans remember about the program is a series of corruption scandals and contentious efforts to recover stolen money.
